raw_text:
Boateng to step down at election
 
 Paul Boateng, Chief Secretary to the Treasury, is to step down as a Labour MP at the forthcoming general election.
 
 Mr Boateng, 53, is to become the UK's high commissioner to South Africa. He was the UK's first black cabinet minister when appointed to his post in 2002, promoted from the Home Office, where he had been prisons minister. Mr Boateng served on the Greater London Council before being elected to Parliament in 1987, declaring "today Brent South, tomorrow Soweto". He will succeed the previous High Commissioner, Ann Grant, shortly after the next election, which is widely expected to be held on 5 May. The appointment is dependent on Labour's re-election.
 
 Prime Minister Tony Blair said: "Paul has been both a valued colleague and a trusted friend for many years. "He has made an immense contribution to public life in Britain and I am delighted that he has agreed to continue that service to the people of Britain by acting as their representative in South Africa." Chancellor Gordon Brown said: "Over the past eight years Paul's contribution to the Treasury and the government has been exceptional - and it has been my privilege to have worked closely with him closely at the Treasury. "I congratulate Paul on his new appointment. "He has displayed huge dedication to the cause of African development for many years and it is fitting that, in this year of challenge and opportunity for the African continent, Paul has been given such a pivotal role in our fight against poverty and injustice. "I look forward to continuing to work with Paul on this vital agenda."
 
 Mr Boateng said: "I am honoured to be asked to take on this role, especially as it comes at such an integral time for our relationship with South Africa and the African continent. "There shall be many new challenges and opportunities ahead and I look forward to embracing them with great anticipation." Asked if he was appointed as the result of a "fair and open" competition, he replied: "I have been appointed as a result of a process that's been used before by Labour and Conservative governments to appoint people of all parties who have relevant experience." Mr Boateng also laughed off suggestions that his re-election in Brent South seat had been in danger saying it was "one of the safest Labour seats in the country". Shadow foreign secretary Michael Ancram said that, if in government, he would refuse to approve either Mr Boateng's appointment or that of ex-Cabinet minister Helen Liddell as high commissioner to Australia. "Mr Blair's appointment of Paul Boateng is the latest example of a worrying trend of failed Tony's cronies being appointed to senior diplomatic posts," he said.
llama3.2:1b: Paul Boateng will step down as Labour MP at the upcoming general election and become UK's new High Commissioner to South Africa, replacing Ann Grant.
Boateng was first appointed to the Home Office in 2002, promoting him to prisons minister before entering Parliament in 1987.
He previously served on the Greater London Council and has been a valued colleague and friend of Tony Blair and Gordon Brown.
llama3.2:3b: Paul Boateng, Chief Secretary to the Treasury, will step down as Labour MP and become UK High Commissioner to South Africa shortly after the next general election, which is expected on May 5.
He will succeed Ann Grant if Labour re-elected.
The appointment depends on his party's success.

The appointment is contingent on Labour's re-election and follows a long career in public service with notable achievements including serving on the Greater London Council and being the first black cabinet minister in the UK.

He has become the UK's first black cabinet minister when appointed by his predecessor, John Smith, and has previously been in the role since 1987.
The appointment is expected to be made dependent on Labour's re-election.
Mr Boateng was a senior member of the Greater London Council before being elected to Parliament.

Mr Boateng will succeed Ann Grant shortly after next election expected on May 5th.
Former PM Tony Blair praised his contribution to public life, while Chancellor Gordon Brown highlighted his dedication to African development.
Shadow foreign secretary Michael Ancram criticized the appointment citing lack of fair competition and suggested refusal for high commissioner position if in government.
opencoder:1.5b: Paul Boateng, as Chief Secretary to the Treasury, has announced an appointment for the next Labour Prime Minister at the forthcoming general election in South Africa.
He was also elected as the first black cabinet minister when his post was appointed.
He served on the Greater London Council and declared "today Brent South, tomorrow Soweto" when he became a member of the public.
The appointment is dependent on the election of Mr Grant to become the new High Commissioner following the next general election in 5 May.
With Labour's re-election, Paul Boateng will make a significant contribution to the country's public life and carry on his role as a representative in South Africa.

deepseek-r1:1.5b: Paul Boateng will step down as Chief Secretary to the Treasury at the upcoming general election.
He will be the UK's High Commissioner to South Africa, having served as Greater London Council and prison minister before being elected to Parliament in 1987.
His re-election is dependent on Labour's success, highlighting his pivotal role in addressing African challenges.
tinyllama:1.1b: A key point in the text is that UK Prime Minister Tony Blair has agreed to appoint Labour MP Paul Boateng as the UK's High Commissioner to South Africa, which is expected to happen shortly after the upcoming general election on May 5th.
The text also mentions his appointment is contingent on Labour's re-election, and that his predecessor Ann Grant has been promoted to a new position on the Great Lakes Council.

Despite speculation regarding a potentially "faithful and open" competition, Boateng was appointed as a result of a process used previously by both Labour and Conservative governments to appoint people with relevant experience.

Shadow foreign secretary Michael Ancraig expressed reservations about Boateng's re-election in Brent South seat due to concerns that it could jeopardize the safety of safe Labour seats, but ultimately dismissed suggestions that he was appointed as a result of a "faithful and open" competition.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Paul Boateng, a respected British public servant who has held various influential positions in the Treasury, is set to leave his Parliament seat in Brent South and take up a role as the UK's high commissioner to South Africa following an election on May 5th.
Boateng's appointment will be dependent on Labour's re-election and the possibility of his predecessor, Ann Grant, remaining in her current position as South African High Commissioner.
The appointment is likely to be controversial, given that many have questioned the fairness and transparency of the process used to select him for this role.
phi:2.7b: Paul Boateng, former Cabinet Minister and first black cabinet member, will step down as an MP for Brent South in the upcoming general election and become the UK's high commissioner to South Africa.
He is set to succeed Ann Grant after Labour's re-election in May.
The appointment process was open to members of all parties with relevant experience.
Despite concerns from some politicians about failed Tony Blair's cronies being appointed, Mr Boateng said he would continue to work towards African development as a pivotal role for the UK.

He was the first black cabinet minister when promoted to the Home Office and served on the Greater London Council before being elected to Parliament in 1987.
His appointment is dependent on Labour's re-election.
Prime Minister Tony Blair thanked him for his contribution to public life in Britain and praised his dedication to African development.
Chancellor Gordon Brown also expressed his congratulations and looked forward to working with Mr. Boateng on the fight against poverty and injustice.
Mr. Boateng said he was honored to take up the role of high commissioner to South Africa and would embrace new challenges and opportunities with anticipation.
